moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4: introducing the Scotch party, I picked up in a wild blitz game recently: it yielded good results; Black has to react: of course, letting White play d5 is no option...
moves.3... exd4 4. Nxd4: Classical Scotch: White could consider the Scotch gambit and ignore d4 for now, after Bc4, Bc5, c3!, or play c3, dxc3, Nxc3, with interesting play for both sides...
moves.4... Bc5 5. Nf5: theory usually continues with Be3, Qf6, c3, Nge7, Nc2, Bxe3, Nxe3, 0-0, or Be3, Bb6, Bc4, d6, Nc3, Nf6; all this being said, I wanted to try something else: however you look at it, g7 is still a bit of an issue...
moves.5... Qf6 6. Nc3: Blacks' response is in line with theory, and the safest: but now, White is introducing an early Nd5, and Nf6 is not at hand anymore; not very common, in this opening...
moves.6... Nge7: a weaker position for Blacks' KN: but pretty much forced...
moves.7... Bxe3: not good, in this variation: better Bb4, Nxe7, Bxc3+, bxc3, Qxe7, and eliminate the White Knights before it is too late...
moves.8. Nxe3: in this constellation, White has two Knights that can travel to square d5...
moves.8... O-O 9. Qf3: not good is Qxf3, gxf3, d6, Nb5: also Nd5 after this move, is not nice; both threatening pawn c7...
moves.10. Rd1 Qc5: or Qb4, Nc4, Re8, a3, Qc5...
moves.11. Qe2 a6 12. Ned5 Nb4: the first signs of fatigue in the Black camp; better of course Nxd5, exd5, Na7, d6, Qb4, dxc7, b5!...
moves.13. Nxe7+ Qxe7 14. a3 Nc6 15. Nd5: finally: this forces the Queen back to home base; White has won the opening: Qd6, is met with Nb6, and Qe5 is met with finally c3; after Qg5, f4, Qd8: also, White is ready for f4 or b4...
moves.16... Re8 17. Qf3 f5: too eager for play: best is d6, Bd3, Nd4, Qf2, Nc6, 0-0, Bg4; this is only helping White...
moves.18. Bd3 Nd4: also very dubious: better d6, 0-0, Be6, c3, Bxd5...
moves.19. Qf2: Blacks' center will not hold: he has to retreat or he will lose the misplaced Knight; after Nc6, 0-0!, fxe4, Rde1!, White is already better...
moves.19... c5: of course, this can never be a sound move: by now, the move c3 is ready to enter the game...
moves.20. c3 fxe4: after Nc6, e5, d6 (Black has to cover c5), Ne3!, Blacks' center collapses...
moves.21. Bc4 e3 22. Qg3 Nc2+ 23. Ke2 d6 24. B: all pretty much forced: here however, Black had to play Nxa3, bxa3, Kh8, with at least two pawns for the lost Knight; with the LSB landing on square c2,  White will walk right over Blacks' position...
moves.25. Bxc2 Bxd5 26. Rxd5 Qb6 27. Rb1 Qb5+: it is hard for Black the find the better moves, if any: however, Re4, Rxh7, Rxc4, was to be preferred over this any day...
moves.31. Qg5: tightening the thumb screws further: after gxh5???, Qf6+, it is time to make up the obituaries...
moves.31... d5: trying a last desperado breakout attempt: better is Re7, Qf6+, Rf7...
moves.32. Bxd5 Re6 33. Bxe6: all forced by now: and all this, for just one moot check...
moves.33... Qd2+ 34. Kf3 gxh5 35. f5: White has no fear for Qf2+, Ke4, Qc2+, Ke5, with an upcoming mate after Kf6: for Black that is...
moves.35... h6: at this point, one of the moves that leads straight to mate: better Ke8, f6, Qd6...
the culprit is arrested: meanwhile, Black is fighting an upcoming mate on the other side of the board...
moves.39... Qe5+ 40. Kf3 Qd6 41. Bf5 Ra7 42. R: Black finally gets to develop the Queens' wing: here, I announced mate in three...
moves.44. Rd1+ Rd7 45. Rxd7+ Kc8 46. Qf8#: the sound of war pipes and drums, must have been ringing in Blacks' ears a long while after this...

gameName: Fierce Queen crossing the Scottish Highlands...
